journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Image-based approach to optimize the tyre pitch sequence for a reduction in the air-pumping noise based on a genetic algorithm

contrib-group.aff: Acoustics and Vibration Signal Processing Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Inha University, Incheon, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: Sang-Kwon Lee, Acoustics and Vibration Signal Processing Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Inha University, 253 Yonghyun-Dong, Nam-Gu, Incheon 402-751, Republic of Korea. Email: sangkwon@inha.ac.kr

abstract.p: The paper presents a novel approach to solving problems involved in the application of a genetic algorithm to determine the optimal tyre pitch sequence to reduce the tyre air-pumping noise which is generated by the repeated compression and expansion of the air cavity between the tyre pitch and the road surface. The genetic algorithm was used to determine the optimal tyre pitch sequence with a low level of tyre air-pumping noise using the image-based air-pumping model. In the genetic algorithm used in previous studies, there are a number of problems related to the encoding structure and the selection of an objective function. This paper proposes a single encoding element with five integers, a divergent objective function based on an evolutionary process, and the optimal evolutionary rate based on the Shannon entropy in an attempt to solve the problems. The results of the proposed genetic algorithm with an evolutionary process are compared with those of a randomized algorithm. The randomized algorithm is a traditional method used to obtain the tyre pitch sequence. It was confirmed that the genetic algorithm more effectively reduces the peak value of the predicted tyre air-pumping noise. The consistency and cohesion of the obtained simulation results are also improved.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Tyre air-pumping noise is one of the major noise sources of noise inside a vehicle. In terms of psychoacoustics, the annoyance caused by noise sources inside a passenger car highly depends on the relative relationships between the noise sources.1–5 Therefore, in an electric-powered vehicle,6–8 the tyre air-pumping noise becomes important because other noises such as engine noise and transmission noise are not present in the cabin of a vehicle. In this sense, this research aims to reduce the tyre air-pumping noise which is generated by the repeated compression and expansion of the air cavity between the tyre pitch and the road surface.9–11 It focuses on how to predict the tyre air-pumping noise and to optimize the tyre pitch sequence without using complicated numerical methods. For a prediction of the tyre air-pumping noise, a hybrid prediction method12 is suggested that combines the computational fluid dynamics (CFD) method and the Kirchhoff integral method. However, its computational load is the highest. Moreover, whenever the shape of the tyre pitch length is changed, the finite element model for a CFD analysis must be modified repeatedly, which naturally increases the cost and the time needed during the development process. A square-wave-based method13,14 was presented to predict the tyre air-pumping noise roughly by Fourier modelling the tyre pitch sequence with a square wave. The computational load is relatively low in this method and the effects of minor pitch elements on the tyre pitch length can be ignored owing to the limitations of the Fourier transform method; however, this is not true for the groove elements, which are one of the major pattern elements. An image-based analysis method15 was introduced to predict the tyre air-pumping noise directly by modelling the air pumping in a pixel-based image format. This method makes it possible to consider the effects of the depth and the minor pitch elements in detail with a relatively small amount of computation. The functional requirement to predict the tyre air-pumping noise is to ensure sufficient accuracy within a short time in spite of the frequent modifications, as the tyre pitch length is frequently modified by the close collaboration between the designer and the engineer at the beginning of the development process of the tyre pattern. For this reason, the image-based method is popular. In the image-based method, the optimization algorithm for the optimal tyre pitch sequence is important. Although the tyre air-pumping noise is affected by the various design parameters and the environment conditions, it can be modelled simply as a function of the tyre pitch pattern shape, the leading edge shape and the pitch sequence, as shown in Figure 1. Among these three design parameters, the tyre pitch sequence is commonly recognized in many research papers as an independent design parameter having a high degree of freedom in reducing the air-pumping noise. The performance levels of heuristic algorithms were compared in the process of finding the optimal tyre pitch sequence,13,14 and it was concluded that the genetic algorithm is more useful than other heuristic algorithms owing to the relatively small amount of computation and the low possibility of local convergence error. In the genetic algorithm used in previous research, there were some problems in the encoding structure and in the selection of an objective function.

caption.p: The basic structure of the tyre pitch sequence optimization process using a genetic algorithm.
RMS: r.m.s.

sec.p: This paper proposes a single encoding element with five integers, a divergent objective function based on an evolutionary process, and the determination of the optimal evolutionary rate based on the Shannon entropy to solve the aforementioned problems. The results of the proposed genetic algorithm with an evolutionary process are compared with those of a randomized algorithm. The randomized algorithm is a traditional method used to obtain the tyre pitch sequence. It was confirmed that the genetic algorithm as an optimal algorithm more effectively reduces the peak value of the predicted tyre air-pumping noise. The consistency and cohesion of the obtained simulation results are also improved.

sec.title: Image-based tyre air-pumping noise analysis
sec.p: In the paper, the image-based air-pumping model is used to increase the efficiency of the noise prediction process. It is employed to predict the tyre noise generated by the repeated compression and expansion of the air cavity between the tyre pitch and the road surface, as shown in Figure 2. Its main advantage is the possibility of directly predicting the air-pumping noise with sufficient accuracy over a short time from a pixel-based tyre pitch image without a complicated numerical process. The generation mechanism of the air-pumping noise is derived by applying the Euler equation for a point monopole source which is modelled as a spherical emitter of a radius element with oscillations much less than the radius. If the spherical emitter is centred at the origin, all the wave propagation parameters are functions of only the radial distance r and the time t. The gradient of the pressure is in the radial direction; the fluid velocity vector can also be in the radial direction. The wave equation in the radial direction is written as

caption.p: The image-based tyre air-pumping noise prediction method using a simplified air cavity model.

sec.p: Here, the gradient of the pressure is in the radial direction, c is the sound of speed, p′ is the sound pressure and the general solution of equation (10) for the sound pressure is given by

where f can be any function. Assuming that the size of the monopole source with radius a is much smaller than the wavelength of sound, the surface vibration of the spherical emitter related to the sound pressure is written as
where ρ0 is the density of air and ua is the radial velocity at radius a. The change in the volume V is related to the radial velocity on the surface of the spherical emitter, according to
and equation (4) is substituted back into equation (3) to obtain

which means that the acoustic sound pressure emitted by a point monopole source is proportional to the second derivative of the volume change. Here, as shown in Figure 2, the volume of a cube is a function of the length l, the width w and the height h. To connect the theoretical concept of the air-pumping noise model to the pixel-based image format at the pixel location (i, j), the cross-section of the volume should be the unit area. In addition, the length and the width of the cube are constant values of the pixel. Thus, the second derivative of the volume change is simply expressed via the height change of the cube. It is given as
where A is the space term related to the area and in this case A = 1 since unit area is used. Equation (6) is substituted back into equation (5) to obtain

where the height of the cube refers to the depth of the tyre pitch image at the pixel location (i, j), and where the portable grey-map format has 8 bits per pixel to express the information on the contrast of the pixel-based image. Thus, the depth of the tyre pitch length can be expressed with 256 steps. If the radial distance and the temperature are constant, as shown in Figure 2, the sound pressure wave emitted from the pixel location (i, j) of the tyre pitch length can be predicted easily by considering only the second derivative of the height change in equation (7). The non-calibrated tyre air-pumping noise, as the sum of the unit area, is calculated by scanning the tyre pitch image together with the leading edge and time. This is influenced by the tyre pitch image, the leading edge shape and the pitch sequence, as shown in Figure 1. Among the three design parameters, the first two parameters are the dependent design parameters, as the tyre pitch image is not the modification target but the validation target in the present step and because the leading edge shape is mainly affected by the design of the tyre body and road conditions. On the other hand, the tyre pitch sequence, because of its high level of freedom in minimizing the tyre air-pumping noise, is considered as the independent parameter. In this study, for tyre pitch optimization, the basic tyre pitch length given by the Nexen Tyre Corporation of Korea is used to find the optimal tyre pitch sequence for the reduction in the tyre air-pumping noise, as shown in Figure 3. The basic tyre pitch length is modified at intervals of 10% in the direction of travel, and a total of five types of tyre pitch model from 80% to 120% is used for the simulation based on the genetic algorithm. These pitch sequences are arranged by using the random function. The effect of the leading edge shape is not considered here owing to the use of the leading edge in the form of a straight line. The harmonic spectra of these pitch sequences are analysed and their peak value and r.m.s. value were used as the cost function in the genetic algorithm. The r.m.s. value and the peak value were chosen as the variables of interest in the harmonic spectrum of the predicted sound pressure for the tyre air-pumping noise.

caption.p: The effects of tyre pitch sequences on the harmonic spectrum of the tyre air-pumping noise and the selected evaluation criteria.
FFT: fast Fourier transform; RMS: r.m.s.

sec.title: Genetic algorithm
sec.p: This section presents the novel approach for the application of the genetic algorithm to the determination of the optimal sequence of a tyre pitch for low air-pumping noise. Figure 4 shows a flow chart of the genetic algorithm used throughout this research. The processes of crossover, mutation and pitch optimization are required. In each process, novel approaches to improve the convergence speed and stability are presented.

caption.p: A flow chart of the genetic algorithm.

sec.title: Encoding design for tyre pitch sequences
sec.p: Binary encoding using 0 and 1 is used widely to express the genetic information of chromosomes, as shown in Figure 5(a). In the application of a genetic algorithm using binary encoding, two types of problem can arise because of the uncertainty of the correspondence between the binary encoding structure and tyre pitches. The first problem is related to the waste of space inside the encoding structure. To express a tyre pitch, the encoding structure requires at least the three binary encoding elements, in keeping with the eight empty spaces.

caption.p: Structural difference between (a) the binary encoding model and (b) the proposed encoding model.

sec.p: Since only five spaces can be used to correspond to a tyre pitch if we use the binary structure, three spaces are always left behind. Therefore, in order to remove these three empty spaces, in this paper the encoding scheme based on the decimal number format is proposed. The method uses an integer value between 1 and 5, and only five spaces are used to correspond to a tyre pitch. In this case there is no empty space like binary encoding. The five spaces consist of one unit as shown in Figure 5(b), which corresponds to one tyre pitch. In order to express information in the five types of pitch as shown in Figure 3, five units are necessary. One tyre consists of 50 pitches (i.e. 50 units). In this paper, a chromosome consists of 50 units and includes information on 50 pitches. If we use a binary structure, 150 units would be necessary for the expression of the pitch sequence of a tyre. A group consisting of 10 chromosomes is used for the genetic algorithm for optimization of the pitch sequence. Ten chromosomes are repetitively used in the evolution process of the genetic algorithm.

Therefore, the proposed encoding structure can express a tyre pitch without a waste of space using only a single encoding element. Thus, it is possible to reduce the required matrix space size during the computational process of the genetic algorithm, which naturally leads to a reduction in the computational load and a reduction in the time needed for the repeated evolutionary cycles. The second problem is related to the absence of immediacy in the application of the constraints. During each evolutionary process, the two types of constraint should be verified between the adjacent pitches owing to the problems related to the durability and the tyre air-pumping noise.

Because the proposed encoding scheme is based on the decimal number format, without unnecessary ambiguity and complexity, the proposed encoding structure makes it easy to consider the constraints between the adjacent pitches in the application of the genetic algorithm. The usefulness of the proposed encoding structure can also be described by comparing the uncertainty of the correspondence between the two different encoding structures quantitatively. In general, the uncertainty is expressed via the theoretical concept of the Shannon entropy, which is written as

Here, pi is the probability of each case. Table 1 shows the Shannon entropy and the waste of space inside each encoding structure. The uncertainty of the encoding structure was reduced from 3 bits to 2.322 bits at a level of 77.4% with the proposed encoding structure. Thus, the waste of the Shannon entropy was reduced overall from 0.9544 bits to 0 bits. From these results, it can be concluded that the proposed encoding structure is more appropriate for expressing a tyre pitch than the binary encoding structure is.

caption.p: Comparison of the Shannon entropy and the entropy waste between the binary encoding model and the proposed encoding model

sec.title: Design of a divergent objective function
sec.p: A chromosome includes the information on the pitch sequence in the circumference direction of a tyre. The characteristic of the air-pumping noise is expressed in terms of the peak and r.m.s. values of the harmonic spectrum of each chromosome. In the evaluation process, the noise quality of a group consisting of 10 chromosomes is relatively evaluated. The group with good noise quality is dominant and the opposite group is recessive. In order to determine whether or not a group is dominant throughout the genetic algorithm, the fitness of chromosomes is evaluated from the peak and r.m.s. values of each chromosome. The fitness of each chromosome is used by comparing it with those of other chromosomes. This has usually been calculated according to a predefined convergent objective function in previous research.13–18 Therefore, the potential of the optimization algorithm can be limited because of its convergence characteristic as regards the predefined target. For example, even when the optimization algorithm has a sufficiently high potential to optimize the tyre pitch sequence, if the objective function has already achieved the predefined target, the optimization process must stop. Moreover, if there is not sufficient information about the optimal absolute criteria, it is difficult to define the target and to evaluate the fitness of the chromosomes properly. For these reasons, in this paper, a divergent objective function is proposed. In the proposed method, the fitness of each chromosome obtained through the genetic algorithm is evaluated by comparing the relative positions in the two-dimensional normal distribution of the reference chromosomes, as shown in Figure 6. This is calculated through the following procedures. The r.m.s. value x1(k) and the peak value x2(k) are chosen as the variables of interest in the harmonic spectrum of the predicted tyre air-pumping noise. If x1(k) and x2(k) are uncorrelated, the two-dimensional normal distribution can be decomposed into two parts, after which the probability density function of each variable can be written as
where µi and σi are the mean value and the standard deviation respectively of the reference chromosomes. These are calculated using the equations

caption.p: Two-dimensional normal distribution using two types of evaluation criterion.
RMS: r.m.s.

sec.p: Here, x1(k) and x2(k) are the r.m.s. value and the peak value respectively extracted from the number N of reference chromosomes. Each variable of the chromosomes obtained through the genetic algorithm is normalized according to
where zi refers to the normalized position of each chromosome in the two-dimensional normal distribution, and equation (12) is substituted back into equation (9) to obtain

Because chromosomes having a high value in the direction of the negative z1 axis and negative z2 axis are considered dominant objects, as shown in Figure 7, the distance d(k) between a chromosome and the evaluation reference z2(k) = −z1(k) is defined as the sum of the squared variables according to

where k is the integer number corresponding to one chromosome among 10 chromosomes in the one group and d(k) means one of the noise characteristics of one chromosome The fitness of each chromosome is calculated on the basis of the roulette wheel principle19,20 and is a function of the normalized r.m.s. value and the normalized peak value. According to the roulette wheel principle, the total area corresponds to the summation d2(k) of the variation in each chromosome, and the probability P of each chromosome is expressed by

caption.p: Evaluation of each chromosome based on the distance from the reference line in the two-dimensional normal distribution.
RMS: r.m.s.

sec.p: Thus, the fitness of each chromosome can be interpreted as its opportunity to be selected on the roulette wheel, as shown in Figure 8. Figure 9 shows the two-dimensional normal distribution of the reference chromosomes as generated using the randomized algorithm, and Table 2 shows the statistical information. The randomized algorithm is a traditional method used to obtain the tyre pitch sequence. An inverse proportional relationship exists between the r.m.s. value and the peak value, as shown in Figure 9. This relationship reflects an acoustic–physical property of the spectrum of the tyre air-pumping noise. It is difficult to improve both of these simultaneously. Here, the main feature of the proposed divergent objective function is that the potential of the optimization algorithm can be maximized without any limitation, unlike the existing convergent objective function, because the optimization process started from the initial position in the form of divergence without a predefined target. The dominant chromosomes having a high level of the fitness have a greater opportunity to be selected as the parent chromosomes in an evolutionary process such as crossover and mutation through the proposed genetic algorithm. This evolutionary process is explained in the next two sections.

caption.p: The characteristics of the reference chromosomes generated by the randomized algorithm in the two-dimensional normal distribution.
The roulette wheel method for selecting a pair of dominant chromosomes in the crossover process.
The two-dimensional normal distribution of the reference chromosomes generated by the randomized algorithm.
RMS: r.m.s.

sec.title: Evolutionary process
sec.p: Crossover and mutation are the core parts of the genetic algorithm, as shown in Figure 10. First, the exchange of the genetic information between a pair of parent chromosomes is conducted through the crossover process. In general, the dominant chromosomes having a good fitness have greater opportunities to be selected as parent chromosomes. Therefore, the genetic information of the recessive chromosomes cannot be passed on to the offspring chromosomes and will be eventually disappear in the process of evolutionary convergence. Whether or not the genetic information is exchanged between a pair of chromosomes is wholly determined according to the crossover rate. In this paper, five pairs of the parent chromosomes are selected from among a total of 10 chromosomes, including repetition. Unlike the crossover process, the change in the genetic information caused by the mutation process does not come from the parent chromosomes. The mutation process arises only at a randomly selected position inside each chromosome as an unexpected change. Therefore, in the process of the evolutionary convergence, the diversity of the genetic information is more sensitive to the mutation process than to the crossover process. In the application of the genetic algorithm, the selection of the evolutionary rate is an important process. Here, the evolutionary rates need to be selected carefully because an inverse proportional relationship exists between the reduction in the tyre air-pumping noise and the computational load. Thus, the optimal evolutionary rates were selected after identifying the overall tendency obtained through the suitability analysis for various combinations of parameters. Additionally, according to the pitch sequence condition between the adjacent tyre pitches, the changes in the genetic information can cause problems in terms of the durability and the noise. Therefore, as shown in Figure 10, two constraints were considered between the adjacent tyre pitches, as mentioned in the section on the design of a divergent objective function. The first constraint suppresses the rapid change between the adjacent tyre pitches due to the durability, which was limited within a maximum of two steps. The second constraint prevents the continuous repetition of the same tyre pitch for a reduction in the tonal noise components in the tyre air-pumping noise, which is limited within a maximum of two repetitions. After exchanging the genetic information between a pair of chromosomes in the crossover process, if these two constraints are satisfied, the evolutionary process continues to the mutation process. However, if the offspring chromosomes cannot satisfy the constraints, the change in the genetic information will be restored to the previous state, after which the crossover process will be repeated until its constraints are satisfied. The same procedure is also applied to the mutation process, as shown in Figure 10.

caption.p: A flow chart of the crossover process and the mutation process with constraints between adjacent pitches.

sec.title: Exit conditions
sec.p: Excessive repetitions of evolutionary cycles can cause an abnormal convergence and increase the computational load. Therefore, the exit conditions of the evolutionary process should be configured carefully, in common with other optimization algorithms. In this paper, as mentioned in the section on the design of a divergent objective function, the diversity of the genetic information among the chromosomes is used as a quantitative basis to determine when the evolutionary cycle should be stopped. The Shannon entropy is used as the objective indicator to express the proportional relationship between the evolutionary convergence process and the diversity of the genetic information and to express the uncertainty of a system in various fields. Figure 11 shows the changes in the genetic information inside the chromosomes between the initial state and the converged state of the evolutionary cycles. In the initial state, the Shannon entropy value is close to the maximum entropy value of 2.323 bits, as the five types of tyre pitch have equal probabilities. This means that the diversity of the genetic information that the offspring chromosomes can have also becomes maximized. In the repeated evolutionary cycles, the offspring chromosomes, through the crossover process and the mutation process, become similar to the specific chromosome including the dominant genetic information. The diversity and the Shannon entropy also gradually decrease from their initial states in the direction towards zero. In the converged state, the diversity of the genetic information among the chromosomes no longer exists, and the Shannon entropy also reaches a value of zero, which means that the additional evolutionary cycle has no meaning at this point. Based on the evolutionary convergence process and its relationship with the Shannon entropy, to prevent the excessive repetitions of evolutionary cycles, two exit conditions were applied as shown below. The first condition is as follows: if the Shannon entropy value is less than a predefined zero threshold, the evolutionary process converges to the dominant chromosome because 10 chromosomes have the same information about pitch sequences as each other. The second condition is that, if the evolutionary rates have an excessive value, the convergence process becomes unstable and diverges, after which it will be repeated continuously. Therefore, upon exceeding 100 times, the evolutionary cycle was stopped.

caption.p: The relationship between the Shannon entropy and the diversity of genetic information in the process of evolutionary convergence.

sec.title: Selection of the optimal evolutionary rates
sec.p: The diversity of the genetic information inside the chromosomes and the convergence characteristics are affected by the crossover rate and the mutation rate, which are also closely related to the characteristics of the tyre air-pumping noise. In general, although the increase in the evolutionary rates provides more opportunities for reducing the tyre air-pumping noise, it can also cause a greater computational load. For this reason, to find the optimal evolutionary rates at which the diversity of the genetic information and the computational load can be balanced, a suitability analysis was conducted. Here, various combinations of parameters were considered as described below. The crossover rate was divided into 11 cases from 0% to 100% at intervals of 10%, after which the mutation rate was divided into 21 cases from 0% to 20% at intervals of 1%. Therefore, 231 cases were considered in the process of the suitability analysis. In each case, the genetic-algorithm-based simulation was repeated 100 times to derive the generality from the predicted tyre air-pumping noise in terms of the probability. Figure 12(a) shows the relationship between the two types of evolutionary rate and the number N of cycles required for evolutionary convergence. The overall tendency depends on the change in the mutation rate rather than on the change in the crossover rate, and the number of cycles was increased suddenly around a mutation rate of 14%. Figure 12(b) shows the relationship between the two types of evolutionary rate and the number of reversal phenomena in the Shannon entropy, which is similar to the results shown in Figure 12(a). The number of reversal phenomena was suddenly increased around a mutation rate of 15%. Figure 12(c) and (d) shows the relationship between the two types of evolutionary parameter and the characteristics of the tyre air-pumping noise. The r.m.s. value is influenced by the change in the crossover rate, which is between −2.2σ and −1.4σ. On the other hand, the peak value is influenced by the change in the mutation rate rather than by the change in the crossover rate, which is between −1.8σ and −1.4σ. From these simulation results, it was found that the r.m.s. value and the peak value extracted from the predicted tyre air-pumping noise are commonly minimized with the increases in the two evolutionary rates. In particular, the overall tendency of the simulation results sensitively depends on the changes in the mutation rate rather than on the changes in the crossover rate, as a change in the genetic information in the mutation process, unlike the crossover process, does not come from the parent chromosomes as unexpected changes. Figure 13 shows a colour map of the global suitability index for 231 cases. Here, the global suitability S is defined as the mean value of the local suitability factors ŝi. It can be written as
where N = 4 and the local suitability factors are obtained by normalizing the four types of simulation result, as shown in Figure 12. This is expressed as

caption.p: The effects of the crossover rate and the mutation rate on the evolutionary convergence process: (a) the number of required evolutionary cycles; (b) the number of reversal phenomenon in the Shannon entropy; (c) parameter I (r.m.s. value); (d) parameter II (peak value).
Suitability assessment for finding the optimal evolutionary rates.

sec.p: The optimal evolutionary rates were positioned around the highest value of the global suitability. As listed in Table 3, a crossover rate of 70% and a mutation rate of 14% were chosen as the optimal evolutionary rates.

caption.p: The selected crossover rate and mutation rate for the optimal evolutionary process.

sec.title: Simulation results
sec.p: To compare with the results of the randomized algorithm in terms of the probability, the genetic algorithm-based simulation was repeated 1000 times with the optimal evolutionary rates obtained through the suitability analysis in the previous section, after which the tyre pitch sequences of 1000 objects were obtained. Figure 14 shows the normal distributions of 1000 objects obtained using the randomized algorithm and the genetic algorithm. The x axis is the normalized r.m.s. value and the y axis denotes the normalized peak value in the harmonic spectrum of the predicted tyre air-pumping noise. Through the application of the genetic algorithm, the normal distribution of 1000 objects was moved in the direction of the negative x axis and the negative y axis and the cohesion increased. From these results, it can be concluded that the genetic algorithm is more effective at reducing the tyre air-pumping noise and increasing the consistency of the obtained simulation results than the randomized algorithm is. However, the inverse proportional relationship between two extracted features in the harmonic spectrum still exists. Figure 15 shows the change in the probability density in the normal distribution. As listed in Tables 4 and 5, the central position of the normal distribution was commonly moved from 0 to a value around −σ on the normalized x axis. Figure 16 shows the changes in the Shannon entropy during the process of evolutionary convergence; this value decreased from 1.963 bits to 0 bits with increasing number of generations. When the five types of tyre pitch have equal probabilities of being selected, as listed in Table 6, the diversity of the genetic information inside the chromosomes can have a maximum Shannon entropy value of 2.329 bits. This implies that the initial chromosomes that were generated using the randomized algorithm have a high level of diversity close to the maximum level of the Shannon entropy. During the repeated evolutionary cycles, owing to the selected mutation rate, the reversal phenomenon of the convergence curve occurred at around generation 4. The diversity of the genetic information was increased, which provides more opportunities for reduction in the tyre air-pumping noise. At generation 13, all the chromosomes have the same genetic information, and the Shannon entropy inside the chromosomes also reaches a value close to zero. Therefore, according to the predefined exit conditions, the genetic-algorithm-based simulation was stopped at generation 13. Figure 17 and Table 7 show the difference in the averaged tyre pitch spectra between the initial chromosomes before the evolutionary process based on the random algorithm and the converged chromosomes after the evolutionary process based on the genetic algorithm. The r.m.s. value was reduced from 0.3166 to 0.3159 at a level of 99.78%, and the peak value was reduced from 3.4588 to 1.7239 at a level of 49.84%. In Figure 17, if the number of pitches used for a tyre is 50 and they all have the same type of pitch, the peak value of the harmonic spectrum should appear at around the fiftieth order. However, in this paper, in order to express the pitch sequence of a tyre with 50 pitches, five types of pitch model are used. In the optimal condition optimized by the genetic algorithm, ten pitches consist of one type of pitch model. Therefore the peak value of the harmonic spectrum appears at the tenth order. This means that the acoustic energy with a single tone was scattered to avoid the annoyance due to the tonal air-pumping noise. From these results, it can be concluded that the genetic algorithm is more effective at reducing the peak value than the r.m.s. value in the harmonic spectrum of the predicted tyre air-pumping noise. Figure 18 shows the convergence process in the two-dimensional normal distribution during the process of the repeated evolutionary cycles. Figure 19 shows the changes in the tyre pitch sequences between the initial chromosomes and the converged chromosomes. These results show the relationship between the diversity of the genetic information and the convergence process well.

caption.p: Comparison of the two-dimensional normal distribution generated by the different algorithms.
RMS: r.m.s.
Comparison of the probability density in the normal distribution: (a) parameter I (r.m.s. value); (b) parameter II (peak value); (c) parameters I and II.
RMS: r.m.s.
Comparison of the characteristics of the chromosomes generated using different algorithms in the two-dimensional normal distribution.
Comparison of the probability densities in the two-dimensional normal distribution generated using different algorithms.
The change in the Shannon entropy in the process of evolutionary convergence.
The change in the Shannon entropy in the process of the evolutionary convergence
Comparison of the tyre air-pumping noise spectra.
Comparison of the characteristics in the predicted tyre air-pumping noise generated using different algorithms.

The evolutionary convergence process of 10 chromosomes using the genetic algorithm before the evolutionary process () and after the evolutionary process (): (a) generation 1; (b) generation 5; (c) generation 9; (d) generation 13.
RMS: r.m.s.
The change in the combined pitch sequences in 10 chromosomes through the evolutionary convergence: (a) initial chromosomes; (b) converged chromosomes.

sec.title: Summary and conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, a tyre pitch sequence was optimized using an image-based air-pumping model and a genetic algorithm in an effort to reduce the tyre air-pumping noise, as the tyre air-pumping noise is strongly affected by changes in the tyre pitch sequence compared with other design parameters. First, the image-based air-pumping model was used to predict the air-pumping noise directly from a pixel-based tyre pitch length without a complicated numerical process. This method is more efficient than the method based on CFD or an experimental method when the tyre pitch changes length frequently. In the application of the genetic algorithm, a binary encoding model using a value between 0 and 1 incurs two problems related to the complexity of the existing encoding structure and the ambiguity in the process of corresponding to the tyre pitch sequence. Thus, a new encoding model using an integer between 1 and 5 was proposed. The proposed encoding model makes it easier to consider the constraints between adjacent pitches without unnecessary ambiguity in terms of the probability. Unlike the existing objective function having convergence characteristics, the divergent objective function was suggested to evaluate the fitness of the tyre pitch sequence generated by the randomized algorithm or the genetic algorithm. The fitness of each chromosome was used as the decision reference to identify whether or not the tyre pitch sequence has the dominant genetic information; this was calculated on the basis of the relative position in the two-dimensional normal distribution. Here, the r.m.s. value and the peak value were used as the variables of interest. The optimized evolutionary rates in the genetic algorithm were selected through a suitability analysis based on the relationship between the characteristics of the predicted tyre air-pumping noise and the computational load. The results of the suitability analysis showed that the diversity of the genetic information among the chromosomes is more sensitive to the mutation process than to the crossover process in the process of evolutionary convergence. The diversity of the genetic information in the chromosomes was used as a quantitative basis in order to prevent the excessive repetition of the evolutionary cycles, as calculated using the Shannon entropy. The results obtained through the above process based on the genetic algorithm were compared using a randomized algorithm regarding the relative location in the two-dimensional normal distribution. As a result, the centre of the two-dimensional normal distribution was moved in the direction of improvement and the cohesiveness of the normal distribution increased. The r.m.s. value was reduced from 0.3166 to 0.3159 at the level of 99.78%. The peak value was reduced from 3.4588 to 1.7239 at the level of 49.84%. From these results, it can be concluded that the genetic algorithm is more effective at reducing the peak value than the r.m.s. value in the harmonic spectrum of the predicted tyre air-pumping noise; moreover, the proposed method has a sufficient level of usefulness to serve as part of the process of optimizing the tyre pitch sequence to reduce the tyre air-pumping noise.
